## Steps to reproduce

```powershell
 Get-ItemPropertyValue HKCU:\SOFTWARE\ -Name Foo -ErrorAction Ignore
```

## Expected behavior

We should not see the error indicating that the Foo property does not exist.  Note that `Get-ItemProperty HKCU:\SOFTWARE\ -Name Foo -ErrorAction Ignore` behaves correctly (there is no error).

## Actual behavior
`-ErrorAction Ignore` is itself ignored
```none
PS> Get-ItemPropertyValue HKCU:\SOFTWARE\ -Name Foo -ErrorAction Ignore
Get-ItemPropertyValue: Property Foo does not exist at path HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\.
```

comments.body: Good point, but this is a duplicate of #5906; in short: The error that is reported when a value (property) by a given name isn't found should be a _non-terminating error_ (`PSCmdlet.WriteError()`), not a (statement-)terminating one (`PSCmdlet.ThrowTerminatingError()`, as it currently is.
